1676Philistine lords come to Delilah: "Seduce him; see where his great strength lies, that we may bind and subdue him"Conspiring, bribing, strategic. The leaders approach her. Find his weakness. We'll pay you.
1677"Each of us will give you 1,100 pieces of silver"Bribing, massive, tempting. 5,500 pieces total. Enormous sum. Betrayal as lucrative business.
1678Delilah to Samson: "Please tell me where your great strength lies, and how you might be bound"Seducing, direct, obvious. She just asks. No subtlety. The question naked.
1679Samson: "If they bind me with seven fresh bowstrings not yet dried, I shall become weak and be like any other man"Lying, testing, playing. First lie. He's testing her. Seeing what she'll do. Game of trust.
1680Delilah reports to lords; they bring seven fresh bowstringsBetraying, immediate, predictable. She tells them same day. They bring the materials. Trap set.

1682Delilah: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!"Shouting, warning, springing trap. The signal. The test. Will the bonds hold?
1683He snaps bowstrings as thread snaps when it touches fireBreaking, easy, mocking. He breaks them like nothing. The secret not revealed. Test failed.
1684His strength not knownUnclear, mysterious, hidden. They still don't know. The secret kept. Another round coming.
1685Delilah: "You mocked me and told me lies; now tell me how you might be bound"Accusing, pressing, persistent. You lied to me. Tell me the truth this time. Second attempt.
1686Samson: "If they bind me with new ropes never used, I shall become weak"Lying, testing, second round. New lie. New test. Same game.
1687She binds him with new ropes; men in ambush; she shouts: "The Philistines are upon you!"Repeating, testing, same script. Same trap. Different materials.
1688He snaps ropes off his arms like threadBreaking, easy, repeating. Same result. Secret still safe. Test two failed.
1689Delilah: "Until now you have mocked me; tell me how you might be bound"Accusing, frustrated, third try. Still lying to me. You're making fun of me. Third attempt.
1690Samson: "If you weave seven locks of my hair into the web and fasten it with a pin, I shall become weak"Lying, closer, dangerous. Third lie. But now he mentions his hair. Closer to truth. Dangerous proximity.
1691She does so while he sleeps; fastens it with pin; shouts: "The Philistines are upon you!"Working, testing, pattern. She does it. He's asleep. Same shout.
1692He wakes, pulls away pin of loom and webBreaking free, third time, pattern. He breaks free again. Secret still safe. But she's wearing him down.
1693Delilah: "How can you say 'I love you' when your heart is not with me?"Manipulating, emotional, effective. You say you love me but you don't trust me. Three lies. Your love is fake.
1694"You have mocked me these three times and have not told me where your great strength lies"Accusing, counting, pressing. Three times. You keep lying. Tell me the truth.
1695She presses him daily with her words; urges him until he is sick to deathNagging, relentless, exhausting. Every day. Constant pressure. Wearing him down. He can't take it anymore.
1696His soul vexed to death, he tells her all his heartBreaking, revealing, doomed. He can't stand it anymore. He tells the truth. His whole heart. The secret out.
1697"A razor has never come upon my head, for I have been a Nazirite to God from my mother's womb"Explaining, religious, vulnerable. He names the source. Nazirite from birth. Hair is the sign. Cut it and strength goes.
1698"If I am shaved, my strength will leave me, and I shall become weak like any other man"Stating, consequence, truth. Hair cut equals strength gone. Simple. Fatal. The secret finally spoken.
1699Delilah perceives he has told her all his heartKnowing, certain, acting. She knows this is truth. He's not lying this time. She can tell.
1700Delilah sends for Philistine lords: "Come up once more, for he has told me all his heart"Summoning, betraying, final. Last chance. This is it. He told me everything. Bring money.
1701They come up, bring money in their handsResponding, paying, arriving. They come. They pay her. The silver exchanged. Betrayal purchased.
1702She makes Samson sleep on her kneesLulling, maternal, treacherous. His head in her lap. Sleep. Trust. Final vulnerability.
1703She calls a man; he shaves off seven locks of his headCutting, violating, severing. The razor touches. The vow broken. Hair falls. Strength leaving.
1704She begins to torment him; his strength leaves himTesting, losing, realizing. She starts pushing him. It's gone. The strength departed. He's ordinary now.
1705She shouts: "The Philistines are upon you, Samson!"Repeating, betraying, fourth time. Same shout. But this time it's real.
1706He wakes, says: "I will go out as at other times and shake myself free"Expecting, unaware, tragic. He thinks it will work like before. He doesn't know yet.
1707But he does not know that the LORD had left himAbandoned, unaware, horrifying. The worst line. He doesn't know God is gone. Strength without presence. Samson alone.
1708Philistines seize himCapturing, easy, reversed. They grab him. No resistance. The strong man weak. Total reversal.
1709They gouge out his eyesBlinding, torturing, degrading. They take his eyes. Darkness. The seer cannot see. Humiliation physical.
1710They bring him down to Gaza, bind him with bronze shacklesEnslaving, parading, securing. Back to Gaza where he tore out the gate. Now he's chained. Irony complete.
1711They make him grind at the mill in prisonLaboring, slave work, women's work. The hero reduced to grinding grain. Prison labor. Degradation total.
1712But the hair of his head begins to grow again after it had been shavedGrowing, recovering, hoping. In prison, hair grows. The vow renewing? Strength returning? A hint of restoration.
1713Philistine lords gather to offer great sacrifice to Dagon their god, to rejoiceCelebrating, idolatrous, triumphant. National festival. Sacrifice to their god. Celebration of Samson's capture.
1714"Our god has given Samson our enemy into our hand"Attributing, praising, theological. They give credit to Dagon. Their god beat Israel's God. Theological claim.
1715When their hearts are merry, they say: "Call Samson, that he may entertain us"Mocking, cruel, entertaining. Drunk and happy, they want to see the fallen hero. Bring him out. Make him perform. Entertainment from humiliation.
1716They call Samson from prison; he entertains them; they make him stand between the pillarsSummoning, positioning, displaying. He's brought out. Made to perform. Positioned between the pillars. Unknowingly placed for his final act.
1717Samson says to the boy who holds his hand: "Let me feel the pillars on which the house rests, that I may lean against them"Requesting, positioning, planning. He asks the boy. Let me touch the pillars. I need to rest. But he's planning.
1718The house is full of men and women; all the Philistine lords are there; about 3,000 on the roofCrowded, celebratory, doomed. Everyone is there. Leaders inside. Thousands on the roof watching. Maximum casualties coming.
1719Samson calls to the LORD: "O Lord GOD, please remember me and please strengthen me only this once, that I may be avenged on the Philistines for my two eyes"Praying, pleading, vengeful. Final prayer. Remember me. One more time. Strength for revenge. Two eyes for thousands of lives.
1720Samson grasps the two middle pillars on which the house restsPositioning, gripping, ready. He takes hold. Both pillars. The structure's supports. Hands on temple foundations.
1721"Let me die with the Philistines"Resolving, suicidal, martyrdom. Famous last words. Let me die with them. Suicide as victory. Death as weapon.
1722He bows with all his strengthPushing, mighty, final. He bends. All strength applied. The pillars move. Structure failing.
1723The house falls upon the lords and all the people in itCollapsing, crushing, total. The roof crashes. The walls fall. Everyone dies. Lords, soldiers, civilians. Mass death.
1724Those he kills at his death are more than those he killed in his lifeIronic, tragic, mathematical. His death more effective than his life. Final act his greatest. Success through suicide.
1725His brothers and all his family come down, take his body, bury him between Zorah and Eshtaol in tomb of Manoah his fatherRetrieving, burying, honoring. Family comes. They take the body. Buried with his father. Proper burial despite disgraceful death.
1726He had judged Israel twenty yearsReigning, summarizing, ending. Twenty years as judge. The cycle closes. Deliverance incomplete. The Philistines remain.

RUTH: HESED IN THE BARLEY FIELDS
1727In days when judges ruled, there was famine in the landTiming, contextualizing, destabilizing. During the chaos of Judges. Famine. Food crisis. Setting established.
1728Man from Bethlehem Judah goes to sojourn in Moab, he and his wife and two sonsEmigrating, fleeing, ironic. From Bethlehem "house of bread" to Moab because no bread. To the enemy nation. Desperate migration.
1729Man's name Elimelech, wife Naomi, sons Mahlon and ChilionNaming, identifying, foreshadowing. Elimelech "My God is king," Naomi "pleasant," Mahlon "sickly," Chilion "wasting." The names prophesy.
1730They go to Moab and remain thereSojourning, temporary becoming permanent, settling. Meant to be temporary. They stay. The exile extends.
1731Elimelech dies; Naomi left with two sonsWidowing, loss, reduced family. Husband dead. Woman alone with sons in foreign land. Vulnerability.
1732Sons take Moabite wives, Orpah and RuthMarrying, assimilating, transgressing. They marry foreigners. Moabite women. Outside the covenant. Law violated. Love transcending boundaries.
1733They live there about ten yearsDelaying, extending, settling. A decade in Moab. The temporary becomes long. Integration into foreign land.
1734Both sons die; Naomi left without her two sons and her husbandBereaved, stripped, alone. Both sons dead. No husband, no sons. Total loss. Woman alone in foreign land. Extreme vulnerability.
1735She arises with her daughters-in-law to return from Moab, having heard the LORD had visited His people and given them foodRising, returning, prompted. Famine over. God has acted. Time to go home. Decision to return.
1736She sets out from Moab with her two daughters-in-lawDeparting, accompanied, journey beginning. Three widows leaving Moab. Journey to Judah. Women alone on the road.
1737On the way, Naomi says to her daughters-in-law: "Go, return each to her mother's house"Releasing, blessing, practical. Go home. Back to your mothers. You don't have to come. Proper Israelite release.
1738"May the LORD deal kindly with you, as you have dealt with the dead and with me"Blessing, reciprocal, covenantal. May God show you hesed as you showed hesed. Covenant loyalty language for foreigners.
1739"May the LORD grant you find rest, each in the house of her husband"Blessing, hoping, practical. May you remarry. Find security. Rest equals marriage, home, provision.
1740She kisses them; they lift up their voices and weepFarewell, weeping, emotional. Tears. The parting hard. Affection genuine. Grief shared.
1741They say: "No, we will return with you to your people"Refusing, loyal, insisting. We'll come with you. To your nation. Loyalty transcending ethnicity.
1742Naomi: "Turn back, my daughters; why will you go with me?"Dissuading, logical, arguing. Why come? What's in it for you? I have nothing to offer.
1743"Have I yet sons in my womb that they may become your husbands?"Arguing, impossible, levirate. Can I give you more sons to marry? Biologically impossible. No future with me.
1744"Turn back, for I am too old to have a husband"Practical, realistic, aged. I'm past childbearing. Past remarrying. No hope here.
1745"Even if I should have a husband tonight and should bear sons, would you therefore wait till they were grown?"Hypothetical, absurd, patient. Even if I had sons tonight, would you wait fifteen years? Absurd proposition.
1746"Would you refrain from marrying? No, my daughters, for it is exceedingly bitter to me for your sake"Releasing, bitter, selfless. Don't wait for me. It's too bitter. My grief shouldn't trap you.
1747"The hand of the LORD has gone out against me"Theological, interpreting, suffering. God has struck me. My suffering divine. I'm under judgment. Stay away from cursed woman.
1748They lift up their voices and weep againWeeping, second time, deeper grief. More tears. The farewell intensifying. Parting hard.
1749Orpah kisses her mother-in-law; but Ruth clings to herDividing, contrasting, clinging. Orpah leaves. Sensible choice. But Ruth clings. Physical clinging. Refuses to let go.
1750Naomi: "See, your sister-in-law has gone back to her people and to her gods; return after your sister-in-law"Arguing, modeling, religious. Look, Orpah went home. To her people, her gods. Follow her example. Go back.
1751Ruth: "Do not urge me to leave you or to return from following you"Refusing, firm, eloquent. Don't make me go. I won't leave. The great speech begins.
1752"Where you go I will go, and where you lodge I will lodge"Following, committing, traveling. Your destination is mine. Your home is mine. Total identification.
1753"Your people shall be my people, and your God my God"Converting, adopting, covenantal. Your nation is now my nation. Your God is now my God. Full conversion. Covenant shift.
1754"Where you die I will die, and there will I be buried"Permanent, death commitment, eternal. Until death. Beyond death. Buried in your land. No return ever. Ultimate loyalty.
1755"May the LORD do so to me and more also if anything but death parts me from you"Oath, invoking God, absolute. Covenant oath formula. May God curse me if I break this. Death alone can separate us. Stunning loyalty.
1756When Naomi sees she is determined, she says no more to herYielding, silent, accepting. Ruth wins. Naomi stops arguing. They will go together. Three widows become two.
1757They go on until they come to BethlehemTraveling, arriving, returning. The journey completed. Back to Judah. Homecoming beginning.
1758When they come to Bethlehem, the whole town is stirred because of themArriving, public, noticed. The town buzzes. Everyone talking. Who are these women? Naomi returning? Shock.
1759Women say: "Is this Naomi?"Questioning, recognizing, doubting. Is this really her? Changed so much. Ten years and three deaths. Barely recognizable.
1760She says: "Do not call me Naomi; call me Mara, for the Almighty has dealt very bitterly with me"Renaming, bitter, theological. Don't call me Pleasant. Call me Bitter. God made me bitter. Suffering as new identity.
1761"I went away full, and the LORD has brought me back empty"Contrasting, accusing, theological. I left with family. I return alone. God emptied me. Divine action as loss.
1762"Why call me Naomi, when the LORD has testified against me and the Almighty has brought calamity upon me?"Questioning, accusing, interpreting. Pleasant? I'm not pleasant. God testified against me. Afflicted me. Name the reality.
1763Naomi returns, and Ruth the Moabite with her, from MoabReturning, identifying, noting. Official return. Ruth named as Moabite. Foreigner status noted. She came from Moab.
1764They come to Bethlehem at beginning of barley harvestTiming, agricultural, providential. Harvest time. Food. Work available. Perfect timing. Providence in seasons.
1765Ruth says to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean among the ears of grain after him in whose sight I shall find favor"Requesting, working, gleaning. Let me work. I'll glean. Whoever will let me. Humble initiative. Law of gleaning invoked.
1766Naomi: "Go, my daughter"Permitting, brief, accepting. Simple permission. The young woman will work. The old woman will wait.
1767Ruth goes, gleans in field after the reapers; she happens to come to portion of field belonging to Boaz, who was of clan of ElimelekWorking, providential, positioning. She goes to work. "Happens" to be Boaz's field. Providence as accident. Relative's land. Kinsman redeemer positioned.
1768Boaz comes from Bethlehem, says to reapers: "The LORD be with you"Arriving, greeting, pious. Owner arrives. Blesses workers. "LORD be with you." Covenant language in field management.
1769They answer: "The LORD bless you"Responding, reciprocal, pious. Workers bless back. Harmonious relationship. Faith-saturated workplace.
1770Boaz says to his young man set over reapers: "Whose young woman is this?"Noticing, asking, interested. He sees Ruth. Who is she? Not recognition, but noticing. Attention drawn.
1771Servant: "She is the young Moabite woman who came back with Naomi from Moab"Identifying, explaining, foreign. The Moabite. Came with Naomi. Foreigner status clear. But connection to Naomi noted.
1772"She said, 'Please let me glean and gather among the sheaves after the reapers'"Reporting, quoting, humble. She asked permission. Polite. Humble. Proper protocol.
1773"She came, and she has continued from early morning until now, except for a short rest"Praising, hardworking, observing. She's been working all day. Almost no rest. Diligent. Worth noticing.
1774Boaz says to Ruth: "Now, listen, my daughter"Addressing, fatherly, kind. "My daughter." Protective, not romantic yet. Kindness from elder to younger.
1775"Do not go to glean in another field or leave this one, but keep close to my young women"Protecting, providing, including. Stay here. Don't go elsewhere. Stay with my workers. Safe gleaning guaranteed.
1776"Let your eyes be on the field that they are reaping, and go after them"Instructing, practical, including. Watch where they reap. Follow them. You're part of the team now.
1777"Have I not charged the young men not to touch you?"Protecting, commanding, serious. I told the men: hands off. You're safe here. Protection from harassment guaranteed.
1778"When you are thirsty, go to the vessels and drink what the young men have drawn"Providing, generous, equal. Drink the workers' water. You're not just a gleaner. You're treated as worker. Generosity beyond law.
1779Ruth falls on her face, bows to the ground: "Why have I found favor in your eyes, that you should take notice of me, since I am a foreigner?"Prostrate, grateful, questioning. Extreme gratitude. Face to ground. Why are you kind to me? I'm a foreigner. Outsider status acknowledged. Grace recognized as grace.
1780Boaz: "All that you have done for your mother-in-law since the death of your husband has been fully told to me"Answering, knowing, hearing. I know what you did. How you stayed with Naomi. Leaving your land. Loyalty reported. Hesed recognized.
1781"How you left your father and mother and native land and came to a people you did not know before"Recounting, recognizing, echoing Abraham. You left everything. Came to strangers. Abrahamic journey. Faith journey recognized.
1782"The LORD repay you for what you have done, and a full reward be given you by the LORD, God of Israel"Blessing, covenantal, theological. May YHWH reward you. Full reward. God of Israel. He's including her in covenant blessings.
1783"Under whose wings you have come to take refuge"Metaphorical, protecting, intimate. Under His wings. Refuge language. Maternal bird image. She has come under divine protection.
1784Ruth: "I have found favor in your eyes, my lord, for you have comforted me and spoken kindly to your servant"Thanking, humble, status. I've found favor. You comforted me. You spoke kindly. "Your servant" even though she's not his servant. Humility extreme.
1785"Though I am not one of your servants"Clarifying, humble, realistic. I'm not even that. I'm lower than your servants. I'm outside. Yet you're kind. Grace magnified by status gap.
1786At mealtime Boaz says: "Come here and eat bread and dip your morsel in the wine"Inviting, including, generous. Come eat with us. Eat my bread. Dip in the wine. Meal invitation. Intimacy deepening. Gleaner to guest.
1787She sits beside the reapers; he passes to her roasted grain; she eats until satisfied and has some leftEating, satisfied, abundance. She sits with workers. He serves her personally. She eats. Full. Leftovers. More than enough. Overflow.
1788When she gets up to glean, Boaz instructs his young men: "Let her glean even among the sheaves, and do not reproach her"Commanding, protecting, generous beyond law. Let her glean where she shouldn't normally glean. Don't scold her. Grace beyond legal requirement.
1789"Also pull out some from the bundles for her and leave it for her to glean; do not rebuke her"Commanding, sabotaging harvest for her benefit, extravagant. Deliberately drop grain for her. Make her gleaning easy and abundant. Generosity as conspiracy.
1790Ruth gleans in field until evening; beats out what she gleaned: about an ephah of barleyWorking, threshing, abundant. All day. Then she threshes it. An ephah: about 29 pounds. Far more than normal gleaning. Impossible quantity. Providence and human kindness together.
1791She takes it up, goes into the city; mother-in-law sees what she gleaned; she brings out and gives her what food she had left over after being satisfiedReturning, showing, giving. Back to Naomi. Look how much. Here's what I gleaned. And here's leftovers from lunch. Abundance shared.
1792Naomi: "Where did you glean today? Where have you worked? Blessed be the man who took notice of you"Asking, amazed, blessing. Where did you get all this? Someone was very kind. Bless him. Recognition of extraordinary provision.
1793Ruth tells her mother-in-law with whom she worked: "The man's name is Boaz"Reporting, naming, simple. I worked in Boaz's field. The name dropped. Naomi's reaction coming.
1794Naomi says to Ruth: "May he be blessed by the LORD, whose kindness has not forsaken the living or the dead"Blessing, theological, covenantal. Bless him. God's hesed continuing. To living and dead. Covenant loyalty still active. Even in exile and return, God's faithfulness continues through Boaz.
1795"The man is a close relative of ours, one of our redeemers"Explaining, hopeful, legal. He's family. A goel. Kinsman redeemer. Legal right and obligation to help. This isn't just kindness. This is covenant family obligation. Hope kindled.
1796Ruth: "Besides, he said to me, 'You shall keep close by my young men until they have finished all my harvest'"Reporting, including, ongoing. He said stay with his workers. All harvest long. Weeks of provision guaranteed. Protection extended through harvest season.
1797Naomi: "It is good, my daughter, that you go out with his young women, lest in another field you be assaulted"Approving, protective, wise. Yes, stay with his workers. Safer there. Other fields dangerous. Wise counsel. Protecting Ruth from sexual violence.
1798Ruth keeps close to young women of Boaz, gleaning until end of barley and wheat harvests; she lives with her mother-in-lawWorking, safe, living. All harvest season. Barley, then wheat. Weeks. She stays with Naomi. Provision through labor. Security established.
1799When barley and wheat harvests are ended, Naomi says to Ruth: "My daughter, should I not seek rest for you, that it may be well with you?"Scheming, motherly, practical. Harvests done. What next? Let me find you a home. Security. Marriage. Matchmaking begins.
1800"Is not Boaz our relative, with whose young women you were? See, he is winnowing barley tonight at the threshing floor"Identifying, timing, planning. Boaz is family. Tonight he's winnowing. At the threshing floor. Opportunity presenting. Plan forming.

1801Naomi: "Wash, anoint yourself, put on your cloak, go down to the threshing floor; do not make yourself known until he has finished eating and drinking"Instructing, ritualing, strategic. Prepare yourself. Bathe, perfume, best clothes. Go to him. But wait. Timing matters. Let him eat first. Wine and food before approach.
1802"When he lies down, observe where he lies. Then go, uncover his feet, lie down"Bold, intimate, ritual. Watch where he sleeps. Go to him. Uncover his feet. Lie there. Marriage proposal performed through symbolic action. Risky. Unconventional. Legally significant.
1803"He will tell you what to do"Trusting, submitting, waiting. He'll know what this means. He'll respond. The move is yours, but the decision is his.
1804Ruth: "All that you say I will do"Obedient, trusting, brave. I'll do it. No questions. Trust in Naomi's plan. Faith in this

 strategy.
1805She goes down to the threshing floor, does according to all her mother-in-law commandedObeying, acting, following. She does exactly as told. Washes, anoints, goes. Obedience complete.
1806Boaz eats, drinks, his heart is merry; he goes to lie down at end of heap of grainSatisfied, cheerful, vulnerable. Good harvest. Good meal. Wine. Happy. He sleeps by the grain. Protecting it. Sleeping outdoors. Exposed.
1807She comes softly, uncovers his feet, lies downStealthy, symbolic, intimate. Quietly. Uncovers feet. Lies there. The gesture made. Marriage proposal through touch and proximity.
1808At midnight the man is startled, turns over; a woman lying at his feetWaking, shocked, confused. Middle of night. He wakes. A woman here. At his feet. Who?
1809He says: "Who are you?"Questioning, disoriented, urgent. Who is this? What's happening?
1810She answers: "I am Ruth, your servant. Spread your wings over your servant, for you are a redeemer"Identifying, requesting, covenantal. I'm Ruth. Spread your wing over me. Marry me. You're the goel. You have the right. And I'm asking. Marriage proposal explicit. Cloak as wedding canopy.
1811He says: "May you be blessed by the LORD, my daughter"Blessing, moved, fatherly. God bless you. "My daughter" again. Kindness recognized.
1812"You have made this last kindness greater than the first in that you have not gone after young men, whether poor or rich"Praising, grateful, realistic. This is greater kindness still. You could have pursued younger men. Rich or poor, your pick. But you came to me. Old man chosen over young. Humility and loyalty magnified.
1813"And now, my daughter, do not fear. I will do for you all that you ask"Accepting, reassuring, committing. Don't be afraid. I'll do it. I'll marry you. Yes. Proposal accepted.
1814"For all my fellow townsmen know that you are a worthy woman"Praising, public, status. Everyone knows you're a woman of valor. Eshet hayil. Your reputation is excellence. You're worthy.
1815"And now it is true that I am a redeemer. Yet there is a redeemer nearer than I"Complicating, legal, honest. Yes, I'm a goel. But there's one closer. Legal priority. I'm not first in line. Truth before desire.
1816"Remain tonight, and in the morning, if he will redeem you, good; let him do it"Waiting, legal, patient. Stay here tonight. Morning we'll see. If he wants to redeem, he has the right. I'll respect that.
1817"But if he is not willing to redeem you, then, as the LORD lives, I will redeem you"Promising, covenantal, oath. But if he refuses, I swear by YHWH, I will. Absolute promise. The LORD as witness.
1818"Lie down until the morning"Protecting, proper, waiting. Stay until dawn. Safe here. We wait for light. Propriety maintained.
1819She lies at his feet until morning, then rises before one could recognize anotherResting, discreet, modest. She stays. Dawn comes. She rises early. Before anyone could see and recognize. Reputation protected.
1820Boaz says: "Let it not be known that the woman came to the threshing floor"Protecting, reputation, discretion. Keep this secret. No one must know she came here. Protecting her honor. Guarding against scandal.
1821He says: "Bring the garment you are wearing and hold it out"Giving, preparing, generous. Hold out your shawl. I'll give you something. Practical care before departure.
1822She holds it; he measures six measures of barley, puts it on herLoading, generous, symbolic. Six measures. Heavy load. More provision. Six for the six days of waiting? Symbolic and practical gift.
1823He goes into the city; she comes to her mother in lawDeparting, returning, separate paths. He goes to settle legal matters. She goes home to wait. The plan in motion.
