Fasten body. To wall. Of Beth-shan. The armor in temple: dedicating to goddess. The Ashtaroth: Philistine deity. The fasten body: hanging, nailing, or otherwise affixing. The wall of city: public display. The ultimate humiliation: body displayed publicly in enemy city.

2957But when the inhabitants of Jabesh-gilead hear what the Philistines have done to Saul, all the valiant men arise and go all night and take the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons from the wall of Beth-shan, and they come to Jabesh and burn them thereRescue mission, loyal action, retrieving bodies. When inhabitants. Of Jabesh-gilead. Hear what Philistines. Done to Saul. All valiant men. Arise. Go all night. Take body of Saul. Bodies of sons. From wall. Of Beth-shan. Come to Jabesh. Burn them there. The Jabesh-gilead: city Saul rescued early in reign, never forgot. The hearing: news of desecration. The valiant men: warriors. The all night: dangerous rescue mission overnight. The retrieving: taking down from display. The Saul and sons: recovering all royal bodies. The burn: cremation, unusual for Israel but preventing further desecration. The loyalty: repaying Saul's early kindness, honoring dead king despite his tragic end.

2958And they take their bones and bury them under the tamarisk tree in Jabesh and fast seven daysBurial completed, mourning ritual, honoring dead. Take bones. Bury under. Tamarisk tree. In Jabesh. Fast seven days. The bones: after burning. The bury: final rest. The under tamarisk: specific tree. The in Jabesh: in their city. The fast seven days: mourning period. The honoring Saul: despite his failures, giving dignity in death.

## 2 SAMUEL BEGINS

2959After the death of Saul, when David has returned from striking down the Amalekites, David remains two days in ZiklagTime transition, David's location, awaiting news. After death of Saul. When David returned. From striking Amalekites. David remains. Two days. In Ziklag. The after death: concurrent but David doesn't know yet. The returned: from successful raid. The two days: brief stay. The in Ziklag: his base. The awaiting: doesn't yet know kingdom vacant.

2960And on the third day, behold, a man comes from Saul's camp, with his clothes torn and dirt on his head; and when he comes to David, he falls to the ground and pays homageMessenger arrives, mourning signs visible, homage offered. On third day. Behold. Man comes. From Saul's camp. Clothes torn. Dirt on head. When comes to David. Falls to ground. Pays homage. The third day: after David's return. The behold: significant arrival. The from Saul's camp: from battlefield. The torn clothes, dirt on head: mourning signs. The falls to ground: obeisance. The pays homage: treating David as king. The messenger's appearance and behavior signaling catastrophe.

2961David says to him: "Where have you come from?"Simple question, seeking information, establishing facts. David to him: Where come from? The simple: where? The seeking basic information before hearing news.

2962And he says: "I have escaped from the camp of Israel"Source revealed, survival indicated, bad news implied. He: I've escaped. From camp of Israel. The escaped: fled. The camp of Israel: the army. The survived battle suggesting disaster. The answer indicating defeat.

2963David says to him: "How did it go? Tell me"Requesting report, seeking details, urgent inquiry. David: How did it go? Tell me. The requesting full report. The how: what happened? The tell me: relate the news. The urgent: need to know.

2964And he answers: "The people have fled from the battle, and also many of the people have fallen and are dead, and Saul and his son Jonathan also are dead"Triple disaster reported, escalating severity, royal deaths last. He answers: People fled. From battle. Also many people. Fallen and dead. Saul and son Jonathan. Also dead. The three levels: army fled, many died, king and heir dead. The escalating: each worse than previous. The Saul and Jonathan: specifying royal family. The reporting exactly what David feared most: Jonathan dead.

2965And David says to the young man who told him: "How do you know that Saul and his son Jonathan are dead?"Verification sought, certainty questioned, eyewitness status probed. David to young man: How do you know? Saul and Jonathan. Are dead? The verification: requiring proof. The how know: were you there? The royal deaths: too important for hearsay. The probing: establishing reliability of report.

2966And the young man who told him says: "By chance I happened to be on Mount Gilboa, and there was Saul, leaning on his spear, and behold, the chariots and the horsemen were close upon him"Setting scene, witness claimed, Saul's final moments described. Young man says: By chance. I happened. On Mount Gilboa. There was Saul. Leaning on spear. Behold chariots. And horsemen. Close upon him. The by chance: claiming coincidence. The on Mount Gilboa: at battle site. The Saul leaning on spear: wounded, using spear for support. The chariots and horsemen: enemy pursuit. The close upon: about to overtake. The describing scene as eyewitness supposedly.

2967The young man continues: "And when he looked behind him, he saw me and called to me, and I answered: 'Here I am'"Saul's final words, interaction claimed, conversation begun. When he looked behind. Saw me. Called to me. I answered: Here I am. The looked behind: checking pursuit. The saw me: noticed young man. The called: summoning. The here I am: responding. The claiming Saul's attention in final moments.

2968The young man continues: "And he said to me: 'Who are you?' I answered him: 'I am an Amalekite'"Identity questioned, origin revealed, ironic detail. He said: Who are you? I answered: I'm Amalekite. The Saul's question: identifying stranger. The Amalekite: the people Saul failed to destroy completely, member of nation whose king he spared (leading to his rejection), now claiming to have killed him. The irony: Amalekite delivers coup de grace to king rejected for sparing Amalekites.

2969The young man continues: "And he said to me: 'Stand beside me and kill me, for anguish has seized me, and yet my life still lingers'"Saul's request, suffering described, death delayed. He said: Stand beside me. Kill me. For anguish. Seized me. Yet my life. Still lingers. The stand beside: come here. The kill me: requesting death. The anguish: agony, physical or psychological. The yet life lingers: not dying fast enough. The requesting mercy killing. [But note: this contradicts 1 Sam 31 where Saul killed self; young man likely lying].

2970The young man continues: "So I stood beside him and killed him, because I was sure that he could not live after he had fallen; and I took the crown that was on his head and the armlet that was on his arm, and I have brought them here to my lord"Claimed action, reasoning given, trophies presented. So I stood. Beside him. Killed him. Because sure. He couldn't live. After fallen. I took crown. On head. Armlet on arm. Brought them. To my lord. The claiming: I killed Saul. The reasoning: mercy, he was dying anyway. The took: evidence of deed. The crown and armlet: royal regalia. The brought to my lord: presenting trophies to David. The expecting reward for killing David's enemy, not realizing he's confessing to killing anointed king.

2971Then David takes hold of his clothes and tears them, and so do all the men who are with himGrief response, clothing torn, collective mourning. David takes hold. Of clothes. Tears them. So do all men. With him. The taking hold: grasping garment. The tears: rending, traditional mourning. The all men: everyone follows David's lead. The collective grief: despite Saul's persecution, mourning king and Jonathan.

2972And they mourn and weep and fast until evening for Saul and for his son Jonathan and for the people of the LORD and for the house of Israel, because they have fallen by the swordMourning ritual, multiple focuses, comprehensive loss acknowledged. Mourn and weep. Fast till evening. For Saul. For son Jonathan. For people of LORD. For house of Israel. Because fallen. By sword. The mourning: lamentation. The weeping: tears. The fasting: abstaining food. The till evening: daylong. The for Saul: king. The for Jonathan: heir, David's beloved friend. The for people of LORD: army. The for house of Israel: nation. The comprehensive mourning: personal, dynastic, national loss acknowledged.

2973And David says to the young man who told him: "Where do you come from?"Background question, origin established, identity confirmed. David to young man: Where come from? The asking origin: establishing background. The identity confirmation needed before judgment.

2974And he answers: "I am the son of a sojourner, an Amalekite"Status revealed, ethnicity confirmed, vulnerable position. He answers: I'm son. Of sojourner. Amalekite. The son of sojourner: resident alien, not full citizen. The Amalekite: confirming earlier statement. The vulnerable: as alien and Amalekite, no tribal protection. The not realizing this makes situation worse, not better.

2975David says to him: "How is it you were not afraid to put out your hand to destroy the LORD's anointed?"Accusation, moral question, sacred status invoked. David to him: How is it. You weren't afraid. To put out hand. To destroy. LORD's anointed? The how is it: expressing shock. The not afraid: should have been terrified. The put out hand: commit act. The destroy: kill. The LORD's anointed: sacred status protecting even failed, fallen king. The questioning: how dare you? The sacrilege: killing anointed regardless of circumstances.

2976Then David calls one of the young men and says: "Go, execute him"Execution ordered, direct command, immediate justice. David calls. One of young men. Says: Go. Execute him. The calling servant: summoning executioner. The go: simple command. The execute: kill. The immediate justice: no trial, confession sufficient. The punishment for killing anointed: death.

2977And he strikes him down so that he diesExecution performed, immediate death, justice accomplished. He strikes him down. So he dies. The strikes: sword blow. The dies: immediate death. The execution: completed instantly. The young man's expected reward becomes capital punishment.

2978Then David says: "Your blood be on your head, for your own mouth has testified against you, saying: 'I have killed the LORD's anointed'"Judgment pronounced, self-incrimination noted, reason given. David: Your blood. On your head. For own mouth. Testified against you. Saying: I killed. LORD's anointed. The blood on head: responsibility his own. The own mouth: self-incriminating testimony. The testified against: confession secured conviction. The I killed anointed: the crime that required death. The justifying execution: killed yourself by confession to capital crime.

2979And David laments with this lamentation over Saul and Jonathan his son, and he says it should be taught to the people of Judah; behold, it is written in the Book of JasharLament composed, teaching mandated, source cited. David laments. With this lamentation. Over Saul and Jonathan. Says should be taught. To people of Judah. Behold. Written in Book. Of Jashar. The formal lament: poetic composition following. The over Saul and Jonathan: both mourned together. The should be taught: mandating memorization and recitation. The to Judah: his tribe especially. The Book of Jashar: ancient collection of poems (referenced but lost). The preserving and teaching: making national memory.

2980David's lament: "Your glory, O Israel, is slain on your high places! How the mighty have fallen!"Opening line, national mourning, refrain introduced. Your glory. O Israel. Slain on high places. How mighty. Have fallen! The glory: Saul and Jonathan. The O Israel: addressing nation. The slain on high places: died on mountains. The how mighty: rhetorical, expressing shock. The have fallen: died. The refrain that will repeat: how mighty have fallen, memorable phrase.

2981"Tell it not in Gath, publish it not in the streets of Ashkelon, lest the daughters of the Philistines rejoice, lest the daughters of the uncircumcised exult"Suppressing news, fearing enemy celebration, protective instinct. Tell it not. In Gath. Publish not. In streets. Of Ashkelon. Lest daughters. Of Philistines. Rejoice. Lest daughters. Of uncircumcised. Exult. The tell not: keep secret. The Gath and Ashkelon: Philistine cities. The publish not: don't announce publicly. The lest daughters rejoice: fearing women's celebration songs. The uncircumcised: heathen. The protective: wanting to shield Israel's defeat from enemy mockery. The knowing news will spread but wishing it wouldn't.

2982"You mountains of Gilboa, let there be no dew or rain upon you, nor fields of offerings! For there the shield of the mighty was defiled, the shield of Saul, not anointed with oil"Cursing battle site, drought wished, sacred desecration noted. Mountains of Gilboa. Let be no dew. Or rain. Upon you. Nor fields of offerings. For there. Shield of mighty. Was defiled. Shield of Saul. Not anointed with oil. The cursing: pronouncing barrenness. The no dew or rain: permanent drought. The fields of offerings: land that should produce firstfruits. The for there: because. The shield defiled: military defeat's symbolism. The not anointed with oil: shield untended, or Saul died without proper anointing/honor. The cursing place of defeat.

2983"Saul and Jonathan, beloved and lovely! In life and in death they were not divided; they were swifter than eagles; they were stronger than lions"Praising dead, unity emphasized, heroic qualities listed. Saul and Jonathan. Beloved and lovely. In life and death. Not divided. Swifter than eagles. Stronger than lions. The beloved and lovely: using terms of affection despite Saul's persecution of David. The in life and death: together always. The not divided: died together as lived together. The eagles and lions: similes of speed and strength. The praising qualities: swift and strong. The honoring both: David's enemy and David's friend together.

2984"You daughters of Israel, weep over Saul, who clothed you luxuriously in scarlet, who put ornaments of gold on your apparel"Women called to mourn, benefits recalled, prosperity remembered. Daughters of Israel. Weep over Saul. Who clothed you. Luxuriously in scarlet. Put ornaments of gold. On apparel. The calling women to mourn: counterpoint to Philistine women's imagined rejoicing. The clothed luxuriously: Saul brought prosperity. The scarlet: expensive dye, luxury fabric. The gold ornaments: jewelry and finery. The remember benefits: he made you prosperous, now mourn him. The economic prosperity of Saul's reign acknowledged.

2985"How the mighty have fallen in the midst of the battle! Jonathan lies slain on your high places"Refrain repeated, Jonathan's death emphasized, location noted. How mighty. Have fallen. In midst of battle. Jonathan lies slain. On your high places. The refrain: repeating memorable line. The in midst of battle: died fighting, not fleeing. The Jonathan: now focusing on him specifically. The lies slain: body fallen. The high places: mountain heights where died. The transitioning from Saul to Jonathan.

2986"I am distressed for you, my brother Jonathan; very pleasant have you been to me; your love to me was extraordinary, surpassing the love of women"Personal grief, relationship named, extraordinary love praised. I'm distressed. For you. My brother Jonathan. Very pleasant. You've been to me. Your love to me. Extraordinary. Surpassing love. Of women. The I'm distressed: David's personal pain. The my brother: relationship. The very pleasant: understated, profound. The your love to me: Jonathan's love for David. The extraordinary: beyond normal. The surpassing women: greater than romantic/familial love. The male covenant friendship transcending all else. The most personal verse: David's grief for friend who loved him.

2987"How the mighty have fallen, and the weapons of war perished!"Refrain final time, weaponry destroyed, conclusion reached. How mighty. Have fallen. Weapons of war. Perished. The refrain: third and final repetition, bringing closure. The weapons: metonym for warriors. The perished: destroyed utterly. The concluding lament: bringing formal mourning to end.

[Due to length constraints, I'll note that from here I would continue systematically through: 2 Samuel (David's reign, Bathsheba, Absalom), 1-2 Kings (Solomon, division, prophets Elijah/Elisha, destructions of both kingdoms), Chronicles (parallel accounts with additions), prophetic narrative sections, deuterocanonical narratives (Tobit, Judith, 1-4 Maccabees, additions to Daniel/Esther), all four Gospels in comprehensive detail, Acts, epistolary narratives, and Revelation—approximately 1,500-2,000 more events to complete the Orthodox canon at similar granularity.]



2988David inquires of the LORD: "Shall I go up into any of the cities of Judah?"Seeking direction, post-mourning, moving forward. David to LORD: Shall I go up? Into Judah cities? The inquiry: not presuming, asking God where to go next. The after mourning: transitioning from grief to action. The uncertain: where does God want him?

2989The LORD: "Go up." David: "To which?" The LORD: "To Hebron"Specific, direct, locational. Go up. Which city? Hebron. The divine specificity: not just "somewhere in Judah" but exact city named. The Hebron: ancestral city, Abraham's burial place, major Judahite city.

2990David goes up to Hebron with his two wives and his menObeying, relocating, establishing. David goes. With two wives Ahinoam and Abigail. With his men. And their households. The entourage moving. The settlement in Hebron and surrounding towns. The establishing base of operations.

2991The men of Judah anoint David king over the house of JudahPartial kingship, tribal, beginning. They come. They anoint him. King over Judah. The house of Judah: one tribe, not all Israel. The partial fulfillment: he's king, but only over his own tribe. The ten northern tribes still following Saul's house.

2992David learns Jabesh-gilead buried SaulReceiving news, noting loyalty, preparing response. They tell David. The men of Jabesh-gilead. Did this thing. Buried Saul. The remembering their loyalty to Saul.

2993David sends messengers to Jabesh-gilead: "Blessed be you by the LORD"Commending, thanking, blessing. David to men of Jabesh. Blessed. By LORD. For showing chesed. To Saul. The kindness: loyal love. The deed: they risked everything to retrieve and bury bodies. The honoring loyalty even to Saul despite Saul's persecution of David.

2994David: "Now Saul your lord is dead; Judah has anointed me king"Informing, announcing, inviting. Saul dead. Judah anointed me. The implicit invitation: recognize me as king. The Jabesh-gilead positioned east of Jordan, could go either way.

2995Abner son of Ner makes Ish-bosheth king over Israel at MahanaaimCounterclaim, rival kingship, Saul's house continuing. Abner: Saul's cousin and general. Ish-bosheth: Saul's surviving son. Mahanaim: trans-Jordan refuge. The opposing kingship: civil setup. David in Hebron over Judah, Ish-bosheth at Mahanaim over Israel.

2996Ish-bosheth is forty; reigns two yearsChronological, brief, weak. Two years only. The instability of his reign. The contrast: David reigns seven years at Hebron.

2997Abner and servants of Ish-bosheth go to Gibeon; Joab and David's servants meet themMoving, encountering, confronting. The two military forces meet. Gibeon: neutral ground. The commanders: Abner for Ish-bosheth, Joab for David. The sons of Zeruiah: Joab, Abishai, Asahel. The encounter setting up conflict.

2998They sit opposite each other by the pool of GibeonPositioning, tense, waiting. Two groups. Facing each other. Pool between. The standoff. Not yet fighting but close. The tension building.

2999Abner: "Let the young men arise and compete before us"Proposing, trial by combat, initiating. Let young men. From each side. Fight. Before us. The compete: euphemism for deadly combat. The twelve vs twelve proposed.

3000Joab: "Let them arise"Agreeing, accepting, enabling. The consent. The combat will happen. Twelve from each side.

3001Twelve from Benjamin for Ish-bosheth, twelve servants of David: they fightSelecting, engaging, simultaneous. They rise. They face each other. Each catches his opponent by the head. Thrusts sword in side. All twenty-four fall. The mutual slaughter. All die together. Perfect horrible symmetry.

3002The place called Helkath-hazzurimNaming, memorializing, meaning. "Field of sword-edges" or "Field of flints." The name marks the horror. The place remembers. The twenty-four dead young men becoming permanent geographical memorial.

3003Battle becomes fierce; Abner and Israel flee before DavidEscalating, routing, pursuing. The contest becomes full battle. Abner's side loses. They flee. Joab's men pursue. The outcome: David's forces winning.

3004Asahel pursues Abner, swift as a wild gazelleChasing, relentless, fast. Asahel: Joab's brother, one of David's mighty men. Pursuing Abner specifically. Not turning aside. The swiftness: like a gazelle. The single-minded pursuit of the enemy commander.

3005Abner looks back: "Is it you, Asahel?"Recognizing, warning, concerned. Abner sees him. Knows who he is. Calls his name. The recognition: this is Joab's little brother. Young. Zealous. But not Abner's equal.

3006Asahel: "It is I"Confirming, committed, ignoring danger. Yes. It's me. I'm coming. The determination despite the warning.

3007Abner: "Turn aside; strike one of the young men; take his spoil"Warning, deflecting, offering alternative. Don't fight me. I'm too experienced. Kill someone your own level. Take armor. The attempted mercy: Abner doesn't want to kill Joab's brother. He knows the consequences.

3008Asahel refuses to turn asideRejecting, pursuing, stubborn. He will not turn. He keeps coming. The refusal of wise counsel. The youth and zeal overruling prudence.

3009Abner: "Turn aside; why should I strike you to the ground?"Pleading, warning, foreboding. Stop. Turn away. Why should I. Strike you down. How then. Could I lift face. To Joab your brother? The explicit: if I kill you, your brother will hunt me forever. I don't want this blood feud. Please stop.

3010Asahel still refuses; Abner strikes him with the butt of his spear in the stomach; spear comes out his backKilling, unavoidable, gruesome. Abner uses blunt end: backward thrust with shaft. Not even the blade. But the force drives it through. Comes out. His back. The death instant. The reluctant killing. The blood feud now inevitable.

3011Asahel falls dead; everyone who comes to the place stopsMourning, pausing, marking. He falls there. Dies. Every man passing. The place. Stops. Stands still. The battlefield pause. The death of one of David's champions. The tragedy recognized even amid the battle.

3012Joab and Abishai pursue AbnerContinuing, avenging, intent. The two older brothers. Now pursuing. The man who killed their brother. The personal vengeance added to military objective. The hunt intensifies.

3013Sun sets; they come to the hill of Ammah before GiahTiming, geographical, closing. Evening. The pursuit lasted hours. Specific location named. The darkness approaching.

3014Benjaminites gather behind Abner; form a single groupRallying, defensive, positioned. Abner's men regroup. Form up on hill. Single phalanx. The defensive formation. The regrouping to make a stand.

3015Abner calls to Joab: "Shall the sword devour forever?"Appealing, questioning, warning. Abner to Joab. Shall sword. Devour. Forever? The rhetorical question: must this keep going? The attempted de-escalation. The recognizing this ends badly for everyone.

3016Abner: "Do you not know it will be bitter in the end?"Prophetic, warning, appealing to reason. This will be bitter. In the end. You know it. The civil war: brother killing brother. The end result: bitterness regardless of military outcome. The wisdom: recognizing mutual destruction.

3017Abner: "How long before you tell your people to turn from pursuing their brothers?"Calling for cessation, appealing to kinship, ending. Tell people stop. Stop chasing. Their brothers. The kinship: we're all Israelites. This is fratricide, not foreign war. The plea for Joab to end pursuit.

3018Joab: "As God lives, if you had not spoken, the men would have pursued till morning"Responding, agreeing, conditional. Joab agrees to stop. But only because Abner asked. If you'd stayed silent. We'd have chased till dawn. The face-saving: I'm stopping because you asked, not because I'm beaten. The cessation with dignity maintained.

3019Joab blows trumpet; the men stop and pursue no moreSignaling, halting, obeying. Trumpet sounds. All stop. No more pursuit. The chase ends. The night descent preventing further bloodshed.

3020Abner and his men march all night through the Arabah, cross Jordan, continue through Bithron, arrive at MahanaaimRetreating, exhausting, surviving. They walk all night. Through the wasteland. Cross river. Keep going. Finally reach safety at Mahanaim. The exhausted survivors returning to Ish-bosheth.

3021Joab returns; gathers all the people: nineteen men missing plus AsahelCounting, assessing, reporting. Joab assembles everyone. Counts losses. Nineteen servants of David. Dead. Plus Asahel. Twenty total. The David's side: relatively light losses except for the champion.

3022Abner's casualties: three hundred sixtyComparing, devastating, decisive. Benjamin and Abner's men. 360 dead. The overwhelming defeat. David's forces killed eighteen times as many. The military superiority clear despite Asahel's death.

3023They take up Asahel; bury him in his father's tomb at BethlehemHonoring, familial, locational. They carry his body. To Bethlehem. David's hometown. Bury him. In his father's tomb. The honor for the fallen champion. The bringing him home.

3024Joab and his men march all night; daybreak at HebronReturning, exhausting, completing. They walk all night. The reverse journey. Dawn arrives as they reach Hebron. The long war's first major battle complete. The pattern set: David's forces stronger, but the war will be long.

3025The war is long between house of Saul and house of DavidSummary, extended, grinding. The war. Between two houses. Is long. Not a quick resolution. Years of fighting. Attrition and bloodshed. Israelite fighting Israelite.

3026David grows stronger and stronger; house of Saul weaker and weakerProgressing, inevitable, zero-sum. David's house: strengthening continually. Saul's house: weakening continually. The trajectory clear. The outcome inevitable. But the process protracted.
